subject: RE: [junit] Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: Cédric, Can you elaborate on your statement below that programmers using TDD are guaranteed to miss the big picture? Regards, Kent Beck Three Rivers Institute
messageBody:
Cédric,

Can you elaborate on your statement below that programmers using TDD are
guaranteed to miss the big picture?

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute


_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Cédric Beust ?
Sent: Saturday, October 28, 2006 10:35 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with
JUnit in a big project, please?



On 10/28/06, putnam_david_t <davidtputnam@
<mailto:davidtputnam%40hotmail.com> hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> Cedric,
> I think this is more of what Joakim meant. I had attended a
> presentation by Robert "Uncle Bob" Martin on Test Driven
> development. I think the exact example was a program to keep track
> of a bowling game score. Presenting the Big view object model and
> one done through incremental, test driven development, the later was
> much simpler. It only required the creation of objects needed to
> solve the problem rather then the apparent objects and their
> behaviour.

I have no doubt that TDD works great on such simple problems and that it can
even lead to a reasonable design. Then again, the problem space is so small
that you can argue that no design will really be wrong anyway...

Now consider a more realistic example, such as an application that is
dealing with five database tables, each with four to ten columns, each of
which needs to be mapped to Java objects in a sensible way (i.e. not
necessarily mapping the tables and the objects one-to-one) and should also
include business methods and objects to make it easier to perform
domain-specific operations.

Using TDD to drive such a design is guaranteed to lead to an architecture
that will be focused on solving micro-problems and that will totally miss
the big picture. You are much better off spending a few minutes with a
piece of paper or a white board to design your classes and your object
diagram.

If you want to use TDD to implement this model after that, fine, but I
really dispute the idea that TDD should drive the design in the general
case, because TDD simply never gives you the big picture.

Makes sense?

--
Cédric
